text: <@UUKNHRX41> has joined the channel

Hey everyone! :rocket:

I love being in this community and meeting lots of you during 1:1s, so it’s especially exciting to be doing a Q&A! <@UUKNHRX41> & I are super excited to be here and answer any questions you might have.

We’re content marketing managers and core content team at Doist, the company behind Todoist and Twist!

Todoist is a personal productivity app with 20 Million+ users, while Twist is a team communication app for asynchronous communication. We’re also an entirely remote team and have been for over 10 years.

Becky joined in November 2014. I’ve been at the company since September 2017. Both of us have worn different hats during our respective tenures!

We develop content in a few different places on the web, mainly our blog Ambition and Balance:
<https://blog.doist.com/>

We also produce guides on productivity methods here:
<https://todoist.com/productivity-methods>

And resources on remote work here:
<https://twist.com/remote-work-guides>

We also release a bi-weekly blog newsletter penned by Becky –– we’ll be moving to a weekly newsletter in 2021 which we’ll toss back and forth between the both of us.

ANYWAYS, ask away! Happy to chat about all things content including workflows, reporting, working with our wider marketing team, and anything else you might want to know.

elements.text: Hey everyone!
I love being in this community and meeting lots of you during 1:1s, so it’s especially exciting to be doing a Q&A!

& I are super excited to be here and answer any questions you might have.

We’re content marketing managers and core content team at Doist, the company behind Todoist and Twist!

Todoist is a personal productivity app with 20 Million+ users, while Twist is a team communication app for asynchronous communication. We’re also an entirely remote team and have been for over 10 years.

Becky joined in November 2014. I’ve been at the company since September 2017. Both of us have worn different hats during our respective tenures!

We develop content in a few different places on the web, mainly our blog Ambition and Balance:
We also produce guides on productivity methods here:
And resources on remote work here:

We also release a bi-weekly blog newsletter penned by Becky –– we’ll be moving to a weekly newsletter in 2021 which we’ll toss back and forth between the both of us.

ANYWAYS, ask away! Happy to chat about all things content including workflows, reporting, working with our wider marketing team, and anything else you might want to know.

text:
<@UJE5LQ2JC>  We’re continually refining our data as a company and increasing the scope of exactly what we can track! On the content team, we measure short-term results, but mostly have an eye on how our content performs over time. 

We use a combination of Google Analytics and, more recently, Google Data Studio to assess how engaging our content is and how it performs against our business goals. Here’s everything we report on in Monthly Content Updates:

• Unique page views 
• Average time on page 
• Organic traffic
• Referrals to <http://todoist.com|todoist.com>
• Referrals to <http://twist.com|twist.com>
• Referrals to <http://doist.com|doist.com> 
• New Todoist & Twist users
• Email subscribers
• Average email open rate
• Average email click rate
• Top performing articles 
We stay abreast of content marketing benchmarks when it comes to gauging our performance –– I love talking with other content marketers about this subject, especially when they’re willing to divulge their numbers. Publicly available benchmarks on pageviews, bounce rate, backlinks and more are also really helpful. 

Loved this from Animalz, we compared our numbers to this when it came out: <https://www.animalz.co/blog/benchmark-report-2020/> 

Additionally, we keep an eye on how our content ranks on Google in Ahrefs –– we have close competition in the highly saturated space of productivity and, increasingly, remote work, but manage to have many of our articles appear on the front page of search results, often as #1 or #2.

attachments.title: The Animalz Content Marketing Benchmark Report 2020 - Animalz
attachments.text: We've distilled 150 million pageviews into a dozen strategic takeaways for B2B content marketers.
attachments.fallback: Animalz: The Animalz Content Marketing Benchmark Report 2020 - Animalz

text: <@URB31QKM4> Fun question! Personally, I loved repackaging the productivity guides, moving them from <http://blog.doist.com|blog.doist.com> to a mini site on <http://todoist.com/productivity-methods|todoist.com/productivity-methods>. We also created a quiz to match people with their method. It was a great mix of SEO strategy (a lot of the guides rank very high and have improved since the move) and social/viral (people love quizzes, myself included).

text:
_Strategy Q's_: first off - I've always admired everything Doist - content, brand, ethos, on and on :wink:

1. RE: *SEO and high vol. keywords*. Owning featured snippets like this for keyword _asynchronous communication_ (15K/mo US search vol, 20K/mo globally) is amazing! 
• What's your strategy around deciding _what you write about_? Actively researching/finding relevant topics like this?
2. RE: *updating/refreshing content*. Looks like this async piece, for example, was initially published 2019 and you recently updated article in 2020. How often are you refreshing/updating existing content?
• Do you have some 1:2 strategy (for every 1 _new_ blog post published, updated 2 _existing_ pieces) or otherwise around this?

text:
Firstly, I love Todoist's content, awesome work and thanks for doing this ama :raised_hands:

1) How do you continuously come up with new and interesting content ideas? As well as that, do you have any frameworks/templates for coming up with new topic ideas to systematize the process?

2) Have you had any 'aha' moments that have improved how your content performs (e.g. something you tested, then ended up applying to all of your content)?

text: Deadlines! I'm convinced they're the only way anything gets done. Once something is on the content calendar it creates a sense of urgency. 80% of piece of content is completed within the last 20% of the time leading up to publish :sweat_smile: The more detailed answer is that the time it takes and the number of people involved depends a lot on the specific piece of content. Some can come together in a week, others will require more input from more parties. Content gets stalled on the pipeline all the time. The trick is to always have pieces that are 100% in our control to fall back on in case something falls through. If someone outside the content team is writing it, we won't put it on the content calendar until we have a very solid draft. That way we have a lot of content moving through the pipeline at different rates, but we always feel on top of the calendar.

elements.text: Deadlines! I'm convinced they're the only way anything gets done. Once something is on the content calendar it creates a sense of urgency. 80% of piece of content is completed within the last 20% of the time leading up to publish

The more detailed answer is that the time it takes and the number of people involved depends a lot on the specific piece of content. Some can come together in a week, others will require more input from more parties. Content gets stalled on the pipeline all the time. The trick is to always have pieces that are 100% in our control to fall back on in case something falls through. If someone outside the content team is writing it, we won't put it on the content calendar until we have a very solid draft. That way we have a lot of content moving through the pipeline at different rates, but we always feel on top of the calendar.

text:
Also, we’re working more and more on segmentation as a company! In content this takes two main forms:

* Users Stories
* Guides

For user stories, we try to write about customers across multiple industries that demonstrate multiple use cases. For instance, we’ve covered topics like:

* How an entrepreneur runs a successful business
* How a freelancer stays organized
* How a non-profit employee uses it to avoid burnout

But we also write extremely tactical guides on how different people can use Todoist:

* The Manager’s Guide to Todoist
* The Freelancer’s Guide to Todoist
* The Student’s Guide to Todoist
* The Educator’s Guide to Todoist 

Here’s an example of the latter category:
<https://blog.doist.com/todoist-guide-managers/>

attachments.title: The Manager’s Guide to Todoist
attachments.text: Use Todoist to stay productive and do your best work while leading a team.
attachments.fallback: Ambition & Balance: The Manager’s Guide to Todoist

text: I wish I had a better answer for this – like a system that's super repeatable, but really I just read a lot online, get a feel for the kinds of conversations people are having, what they're sharing, save everything interesting in Todoist projects, add all of my topic ideas there too, and then come back to see which ones are still compelling and which ones are garbage. Most of them are garbage, but if you come up with hundreds of ideas one or two are bound to be good. We do keyword research with Ahrefs to seed ideas too, though we'll only target a keyword if we think it's an interesting and compelling topic in its own right.

elements.text: I wish I had a better answer for this – like a system that's super repeatable, but really I just read a lot online, get a feel for the kinds of conversations people are having, what they're sharing, save everything interesting in Todoist projects, add all of my topic ideas there too, and then come back to see which ones are still compelling and which ones are garbage. Most of them are garbage, but if you come up with hundreds of ideas one or two are bound to be good. We do keyword research with Ahrefs to seed ideas too, though we'll only target a keyword if we think it's an interesting and compelling topic in its own right.

text: Fadeke is also a *great* gut check on which ideas are interesting and which fall flat.

text:
To add to this –– I’m personally a huge fan of time tracking for personal productivity. I use an app called RescueTime and another called Draftback to see how long I’m in a doc.

I would say an average blog post takes at least 15 hours from pitch to publish. Sometimes more honestly haha. Keep in mind we lean pretty heavily into long-form content and typically range from around 3000-5000 words for a lot of our posts!

text: Thanks for the kind words, Georges!  I answered a similar question above from Karine. Long story short, read a lot online and books, generate a *lot* of ideas, have a great team who can help you whittle down to the best ones. I think great blog topics are a numbers game. If you generate thousands of ideas, one or two are bound to be good. We also do keyword research to seed ideas, but are also conscious of the fact that a keyword isn't a topic in and of itself.

elements.text: Thanks for the kind words, Georges!  I answered a similar question above from Karine. Long story short, read a lot online and books, generate a
lot

of ideas, have a great team who can help you whittle down to the best ones. I think great blog topics are a numbers game. If you generate thousands of ideas, one or two are bound to be good. We also do keyword research to seed ideas, but are also conscious of the fact that a keyword isn't a topic in and of itself.

text: RE: 'aha' moments – Not exactly, but over the years long-form content has always performed the best for us. Not length for lengths sake, but content where people feel like they're getting a comprehensive take on the topic. Our content tends to be 3,000+ words but we try to have each one doing work.

elements.text: RE: 'aha' moments – Not exactly, but over the years long-form content has always performed the best for us. Not length for lengths sake, but content where people feel like they're getting a comprehensive take on the topic. Our content tends to be 3,000+ words but we try to have each one doing work.

text: With content like that, you need to make the value prop of reading it clear up front in the intro though. I think I've tended to underestimate the value of that earlier on in my career.

elements.text: With content like that, you need to make the value prop of reading it clear up front in the intro though. I think I've tended to underestimate the value of that earlier on in my career.

text:
<@UV5V2P0VB> Todoist is for both personal productivity and team project management –– B2C and B2B! 

It looks like Click-up is just B2B –– looks interesting! TBH, Click-up looks like a more exhaustive solution based on the landing page –– Todoist doesn’t have spreadsheets, wikis, time tracking, recording etc (though we have many integrations for these things). 

I will say that Todoist Business is create for to-do lists and project management though –– super intuitive, flexible, and powerful enough for large-scale projects. Yes –– one of Todoist’s features is shared projects!

You can invite guests and collaborators to projects to share workflows and checklists.

elements.text:
Todoist is for both personal productivity and team project management –– B2C and B2B! 

It looks like Click-up is just B2B –– looks interesting! TBH, Click-up looks like a more exhaustive solution based on the landing page –– Todoist doesn’t have spreadsheets, wikis, time tracking, recording etc (though we have many integrations for these things). 

I will say that Todoist Business is create for to-do lists and project management though –– super intuitive, flexible, and powerful enough for large-scale projects. Yes –– one of Todoist’s features is shared projects!

You can invite guests and collaborators to projects to share workflows and checklists.

text: Definitely intentional. When you publish content as long as hours people need a break from reading! :sweat_smile: The goal is to make an article as useful for skimmers as people who are reading the whole thing so we're always thinking about interesting ways we could communicate a concept visually both as we're writing and as we're editing. 2 heads are better than one! We usually add a comment to the copy, then go back and create more specific instructions and even super rough sketches for designers so they know what we're looking for. We're lucky enough to have two marketing designers join the team this year and they always take our ideas and make them even better than we envisioned.

We usually add a comment to the copy, then go back and create more specific instructions and even super rough sketches for designers so they know what we're looking for. We're lucky enough to have two marketing designers join the team this year and they always take our ideas and make them even better than we envisioned.

text: In 2021 we want to get better at collaborating with our social manager so that our images are more shareable too.

text: So relate to this! I have like 4 layers of ideas projects in Todoist - junk drawer for random interesting stuff without a topic, topic ideas with literally no filter (if I think it I add it), topic ideas that are somewhat vetted, and a shared project of more or less coherent ideas that is finally intelligible to other people :laughing:

text:
Hey <@UJHT5CHUY>,

You came prepared with some sleuthing haha! ;)

What we write about is largely tied to our products. Twist, our team communication tool is an asynchronous-first and a great solution for anyone interested in “asynchronous communication”, thus the keyword. We do a fair amount of keyword research in Ahrefs around topics like team communication, productivity, and remote work.

This piece is also a rare mix of SEO + thought leadership. It was penned by Amir, our Founder and CEO and really resonated in the tech community. This led to it being widely shared (it landed on the front page of Hacker news) –– and resulted in a lot of backlinks quickly. 

We’re not as diligent with updating as we could be, honestly! That rule is super interesting. 

We’re getting more serious about updating content and will be trying these strategies in the new year:

* Adding low-ranking content we need to update/refresh directly to the content calendar and actually re-publishing it. 
* Taking a publishing pause for a month and having a dedicated “Update” month. 

In the past we’ve approached this in a more ad-hoc fashion! For example, the change made to the async communication article was minimal and on the fly. We also go back and add back links for new posts!

I mostly use it to share my workflows and calendar with my managers and team. It helps create transparency in my process so they know what's in the pipeline when they submit content requests.

text: We forget sometimes too! We're always quick to pull the plug on a topic or give it more time if we realize we don't actually have anything interesting or useful to say about it. It sucks when you've already put so much time into research and/or writing, but we try not to fall victim to the suck cost fallacy. It's all valuable learning!

text:
Thanks for the kind words, <@U01HEMRRPEV>! We distribute our content through a handful of channels:

• *Blog Newsletter*: We publish a bi-weekly blog newsletter with all our latest content. We will be moving this to weekly in 2020. 
• *Drip Emails*: Many of our articles our filtered throughout on-boarding emails for both our products. 
• *User Emails*: We very occasionally do bigger email sends to our wider user base –– this is for product content exclusively. 
• *Website*: Our content can be found throughout our landing pages across <http://todoist.com|todoist.com>, <http://twist.com|twist.com>, <http://doist.com|doist.com>. 
• *Social Media*: All of our content is shared across our social media platforms, we have 100k+ followers across all our channels. 
• *Content Partnerships*: We very occasionally do guest posts where co-marketing is built in! We’ll be exploring this more in 2021. Most recently we collaborated with YNAB on a blog post and Todoist template on getting your finances in order. We worked with our business team to also get the CEO of the company on a Todoist Office Hours (our live video series). 
We’ll be experimenting with these in the new year:

• *Reddit*: I actually made a post about this in #askaquestion last week! Very curious to explore distribution here –– SO many productivity subreddits! 
• *Hacker News*: We’ve had blog posts get tens of thousands of visits in a day from someone posting our content here. We’d love to be more intentional here!

Hey <@U011UJX75PE> We are organized into the following teams:

* Marketing (Content, Product Marketing, Growth)
* Development (Android, Backend, Full-Stack, iOS, Integrations, Web)
* Design (Illustration, Brand, Product)
* Business Development 
* Support 
* Localization
* Product
* People Ops
* Finance
* CXO (CEO, COO, CTO)

Our developers are divided by platform since Todoist and Twist are on multiple platforms!

text:
Great question <@UJG9WTEKG>! It's always a struggle to cover all of the use cases that Todoist can be used for. Plus we also cover topics for Twist. Not all content can be applicable to all of our readers, but we try to get a good mix cover
personal productivity and use cases and team ones. It changes throughout the year and in response to events – Dec + Jan a bit more personal focused, all about remote work last March & April. Our blog is structured to split up those broad topics – remote work, teamwork,
productivity. It helps that our newsletter is biweekly so we always aim for a mix so that people are seeing at least one piece of content that's applicable to them.

text:
That's super interesting, thank you for sharing <@U014UBPTJ0N>! I think sometimes we can get caught up in constantly producing content that distribution almost becomes an afterthought (something I've certainly been guilty of in the past!), so it's really insightful to see how you're approaching this at Todoist.
I'd be interested in hearing how you get on with Reddit & Hacker News, as we've also seen some of our content do well accidently, and now we're trying to figure out how to be more purposeful about distributing there as well. But thanks again, appreciate your time!

elements.text: That's super interesting, thank you for sharing

! I think sometimes we can get caught up in constantly producing content that distribution almost becomes an afterthought (something I've certainly been guilty of in the past!), so it's really insightful to see how you're approaching this at Todoist.
I'd be interested in hearing how you get on with Reddit & Hacker News, as we've also seen some of our content do well accidently, and now we're trying to figure out how to be more purposeful about distributing there as well. But thanks again, appreciate your time!

text:
In content we work closely with product marketing, design, and our full-stack team quite closely! 

Depending on what I’m working on, I might be split between deep work (writing) or working collaboratively with our full-stack team on an upcoming launch (For example, I just spent the last 4 months working on launching our YIR).
